key_points: Hurricane Ida had a significant impact on agriculture and food production along the Gulf and East coast of the U.S.
The hurricane primarily caused land destruction, flooding, and infrastructure interruptions, significantly affecting agriculture.
Louisiana, where the storm hit first, produces about half of the U.S.'s sugarcane. The storm damaged up to 25% of the state's sugarcane crop.
Other Louisiana crops, such as citrus, were also affected due to flooding and increased salinity from seawater mixing.
The timber industry in Louisiana likely sustained significant damage, with estimates of damage to timber land ranging between 5% and 22%.
The Port of New Orleans, crucial for shipping Midwestern soybeans, was shut down until September 7, impacting the shipping of cereal grains.
About 60% of the country's cereal grains go through Louisiana ports, and the shutdown may force rerouting to more expensive land-based shipments.
Hurricane Ida's impact reached as far north as Pennsylvania, New Jersey, New York, and Connecticut, affecting dairy farms and causing flooding on agricultural lands.
New Jersey's largest dairy farm was almost completely destroyed by the hurricane.
The USDA is still assessing the full extent of the damage from Hurricane Ida on agriculture.
